assignments.name: Canvas Oh My!
assignments.notes:
Submit any excused absence documentation here. For COVID-19 exposure or testing positive, use the receipt from the universitys COVID-19 self-reporting form on the TAMU COVID-19 Guidance website.

You may also submit any additional information that might not have a submission place elsewhere in canvas.

assignments.name: Canvas Project 3 Deliverable: Sprint 3 Written Materials
assignments.notes:
Submit your materials for the sprint using the Sprint Materials Template. It should contain:

  • A summary of your sprint retrospective meeting
  • A GitHub release link for the sprint of a working version of the software
  • Updated product backlog
  • Updated sprint backlog
  • Burn-down charts (sprint and product)
  • List of the next sprints SCRUM meeting schedule (not applicable on the final sprint)
  • Appendix with agendas and minutes for each SCRUM meeting in the sprint

 

SCRUM Meetings

You should have at least 3 scheduled SCRUM meetings during the sprint.  This usually means meeting at least every other day. SCRUM meetings should be no more than 15 minutes long.

After each SCRUM meeting, you will create and push meeting agendas and minutes to GitHub as well a submit these at the end of your sprint. The sprint materials template contains a template for the SCRUM meeting agenda and minutes.

Notes on scheduling SCRUM meetings:

  • Lab times and class times (if class is not meeting) or meeting times before/after class are suggested times for some of these meetings.
  • SCRUM meetings must be held after the backlog is created, which is another reason to set your backlog early. For example, if your backlog is set on Tuesday, you can hold your first SCRUM meeting during the lab on Wednesday.
  • Scheduled SCRUM meetings should not be held on the same day as the backlog is set or the same day as another SCRUM meeting.
  • If you have more than 3 SCRUM meetings, which you are encouraged to have, you may hold them more frequently. 

 

Sprint Retrospective Meeting

At the completion of each sprint, the team will undertake a retrospective together. In the retrospective, the team should discuss what went right and wrong during the previous sprint, what changes (if any) need to be made regarding procedure, and what adjustments might need to be made to the product backlog.  

The retrospective should be completed before the next sprint backlog is determined.

 

Backlogs

Your product backlog contains the list of tasks with their priorities, dependencies, time estimates, and status. It should be updated continually throughout the project. 

Your sprint backlog is a subset of the product backlog. It includes the list of tasks that were scheduled for the sprint, who they were initially assigned to, initial time estimates, actual time spent, and their status.

Notes:

  • Task assignments may change as a result of SCRUM meetings.
  • Although your sprint backlog has a due date, you are welcome to set your backlog earlier than the deadline, and begin the sprint earlier (though it must be after the completion and retrospective of the previous sprint). 
  • You should set your sprint goals realistically. You may (and probably will) choose not to include the entire remaining product backlog in the final sprint if you do not believe it will fit in. While your project will be graded on overall accomplishment, it will also be graded on how well you met your sprint goals.

 

Burn-down Charts

You will maintain two burn-down charts: a sprint burn-down chart and a product burn-down chart. Burn-down charts show both the estimated and actual hours over time.  Always report burn-down charts in remaining hours (not number of tasks).

  • The initial sprint burn-down chart is created from the sprint backlog. It should be updated after each SCRUM meeting based on team member status and feedback.
  • The product burn-down chart should be updated once during the sprint and again at the end of the sprint.

We recommend that the SCRUM master keep track of this data in a multi-page google form, where each team member gets a separate page. Each team-member, at the end of each day updates their part in the form (what they think is remaining for each feature he is responsible for). In the form, another page summarizing the total remaining work for each feature, which makes the production of a graph illustrating progress (or lack thereof) easy.

 

GitHub Release Link

You will use TAMU GitHub for managing your code. Each person working on the code should update the code each time a feature is added. There should be regular check-ins of code, and no items should be considered “complete” unless they have been checked into TAMU GitHub.

At the end of each sprint, the source code for the project, to that point, should be turned in by the sprint completion deadline. At the end of a sprint, you should have a completely working version of the software, although some features may not be included if they are scheduled for later sprints. This is called the Minimum Viable Product (MVP) and will be used for user studies. Note that if the sprint is completed ahead of time, this can be turned in sooner (and progress can be made toward the next sprint).

  • Make sure you give the TAs access to your repo as a Collaborator.
  • The project manager should create a release when code is due at each sprint completion deadline.

assignments.name: Canvas Project 3 Deliverable: End-Project Individual Status Report and Retrospective
Canvas Bonus (and Prize) Opportunity: Project 3 Video
assignments.notes:
To get a boost in your in-class activity average worth 1 in-class activity (an extra 10 points will be added to your in-class activity point total, even if it puts you over 100% for that grading category), create a 2-3 minute video advertising and demoing your project.

  • Your video should include the problem you are solving, why it is important, and a demo of your project action.
  • Make sure you do not infringe on any copyrights. If you use a Texas A&M or department logo, make sure you use the official ones (University logos, College of Engineering logos, Department of Computer Science and Engineering logos).

Be creative! (It doesnt have to be a slide show.) Freshman/sophomore students will watch and vote on their favorite video. The winners will get a prize!

assignments.name: Canvas Lecture 2 In Class Activity: Self Documenting Code Assignment Make-Up
assignments.notes:
Assignment Overview and Guidelines

Complete the Self Documenting Code Assignment. In this activity, you will comment and auto-create documentation Java code. (Supply @param and @return for all functions.) You will then host the documentation on your webpage from Project 1.  Once complete, submit your response.

  • Code for self documentation: shape.zip
